content.webTitle: Sean Dyche’s self-belief provides a pillar of strength for Burnley

fields.headline: Sean Dyche’s self-belief provides a pillar of strength for Burnley
fields.bodyText: Just past the halfway stage in the Premier League season, Burnley are in the bottom three and Sean Dyche is cracking jokes. “Danny Ings is not going anywhere,” the manager says. “I’m sick of having to say the same thing. He’s a Burnley player and he’s happy where he is. One day I might turn up for work in a clown suit with a custard pie going ‘Fooled you – he’s gone!’ But I am not expecting to. The club have made it clear he’s not for sale in this transfer window.” Instead of selling, in fact, Burnley have just bought a player, a Manchester United player no less, so how did a relegation-threatened club pull off the signing of Michael Keane without attracting the attention of rival bidders? “I had my cloak as well as my dagger,” Dyche says. “When you have both it makes you a very powerful force. No, not really. The deal was in place since the player came on loan at the start of the season. We felt we could afford to let Michael see what the setup here was all about before committing himself because we knew he would enjoy it, and he has.” Confidence seems to course through Dyche and find its way into his players. Though results have not always gone their way, Burnley’s self-belief has never wavered, and after a tricky opening period and long wait for a first win, recent battling performances to come from behind to earn draws at Manchester City and Newcastle have underlined the spirit in the squad. What Dave Bassett used to term the smell of relegation is nowhere to be found at Burnley’s training ground. Dyche, a no-nonsense former defender turned no-nonsense coach with a surprisingly deft aptitude for man-management, simply would not put up with it. “If we are gaining a reputation for not knowing when we are beaten it is down to the group, not to me,” he says modestly. “Our ability to keep going is probably getting recognised now because of recent results, but people who have watched us for a while will know it is an ongoing trend. We don’t give up, it’s what we are like and it goes back at least to the start of last season. We haven’t just started to recover from setbacks and turn games around, we believe in a relentless manner of playing and have done for a while. It is how we got ourselves out of the Championship.” Fitness plays a big part in Dyche’s regime. All his players must demonstrate the energy levels necessary to compete for a full 90 minutes, though essentially, he believes, the will to win is a psychological attribute that the players work on themselves. “The only thing I tell the players is that games can twist and turn very quickly, you’ve got nothing to lose if you play hard for every minute and everything to gain,” Dyche explains. “It’s a mindset more than anything, but I know that physically they are more than capable of carrying it out. What pleases me is that the players respond to their own demands, not just mine. The inner demand of a group is as powerful, if not more powerful, than the manager’s voice. Once you get the group making demands of itself that can be a really strong force in your favour, and I think that has been shown. Even our substitutes buy into the group dynamic, they come on ready to make a difference. I couldn’t be happier with the unity and determination we have shown this season, but I’m not getting carried away. We still need more points.” The next few games could be crucial in that respect, with Queens Park Rangers at home on Saturday afternoon beginning a sequence of what might be termed winnable matches that will also bring Crystal Palace and West Bromwich to Turf Moor in the coming weeks. Dyche winces at the word winnable. “All matches are winnable, aren’t they?” he asks. “There are never any guarantees, I don’t believe in must-win games except the next one. The next game is always the one you must try your hardest to win. It doesn’t matter who it is against, whether they have just changed their manager or whether they are the defending champions. Points are points, wherever they come from, and you won’t pick them up unless you go into every game with a belief you can get something.” While a win on Saturday would take Burnley above Harry Redknapp’s unconvincing travellers, Dyche prefers to look at the season as a whole and will not set targets or make predictions until the final whistle has blown on the final game. “We are improving,” he says. “That’s something I can be reasonably certain about. Our performance level is rising, we are getting more clinical at the top end of the pitch, we know we’ve got energy because the stats are through the roof, the signs are all good but we have to keep collecting points. The last five games brought us five points, which doesn’t sound a lot but you’ve got to look at who we played against. Southampton, Spurs, Liverpool, City and Newcastle. That’s some fixture list, and an average of one point per game is not bad for a team people were saying would never win a match in the Premier League. Some of the performances were very good too. “Obviously I would have liked another win [the only win in the sequence was Southampton at home] or a few more points, but you have to be realistic. This is a division where teams can get hurt, and we are underdogs in just about every game we go into. We are not in a position to be greedy.”
